div.head: Foreword
div.p: The pages in this foreword have Roman page numbers, just to demonstrate the @n attribute is independent from the page numbering.
For demonstration purposes, we include these few lines of verse from the beginning of “Macbeth”, written by William Shakespeare:

lg.l: When shall we three meet again?
In thunder, lightning, or in rain?
When the battle's lost and won.
That will be ere the set of sun.

figure.p: This text is contained in a figure and mentions Michelangelo.

div.head: Named entities
div.p: William Shakespeare was mentioned earlier in this document, but to get a little more content to play with, we add a few more people: John Montagu, the 4th Earl of Sandwich (and alleged inventor of the Sandwich), Tim Berners-Lee and Alan Turing.

div.head: Indexing @index
div.p: If we want to, we can also index the <index> element. This element can, for instance, be used to define a term for a glossary.

div.head: Handling of <sic>, <del> etc.
div.p:
Certain tags are exluded when extracting parts of the text. For instance, consider the following code:
ShakspearShakespeare. Here, we have an obvious error in the text (marked using <sic>) and its correction. When indexing, TEIShredder will drop the <sic>...</sic> part of the text. The same is true for elements <del> and <orig>.
If you don’t like this behaviour, you can modify the public class member TEIShredder_Indexer_Extractor::$ignorabletags.

div.head: Preface to the Reader
div.p: Due to the overwhelming success of the first volume of this completely useless example document, we decided to publish another volume, which is dedicated to demonstrating indexing several volumes.
